evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was present and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the historical dynamic understanding period prior to the preliminary time zero.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA scenario is resistant to defeaters, as alternative explanations do not sufficiently account for the observed coordination failures.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with the key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident, including miscommunication and lack of coordination during critical phases.

slot_statements.availability: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and accessible within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical dynamic understanding preliminary data.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The procedural deviation in pushback execution withstands scrutiny against potential defeaters within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical dynamic understanding preliminary data, maintaining its validity and relevance.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with the key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical dynamic understanding preliminary data, reflecting typical operational variances.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was present and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the historical dynamic understanding period prior to the preliminary time zero.

assumptions: The communication between flight crew and tug operator is representative of overall crew coordination.
The pushback beyond TRP and collision indicates a breakdown in coordination rather than solely procedural error.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination preventing errors, or if the incident was solely due to procedural deviation without coordination failure.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H4 shows active communication and coordination attempts among crew and tug operators, but the pushback continued beyond the release point causing a collision, indicating observable communication/coordination breakdown supporting the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Ambiguity in whether the continued movement beyond TRP was due to communication breakdown or procedural deviation.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with the key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident, including miscommunication and lack of coordination during critical phases.

assumptions: The described interactions reflect communication/coordination breakdown relevant to the incident
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination preventing errors
If environmental or marking deficiencies were the primary cause rather than crew communication breakdown

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H4 shows communication among crew and tug operators, decisions to stop and resume pushback, and a failure to stop at the designated point, indicating miscommunication and lack of coordination consistent with the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether environmental factors contributed significantly
